response: "{ \"title\": \"Easy: Happy Number\", \"description\": \"A happy number is defined by the following process: Starting with any positive integer, replace the number by the sum of the squares of its digits. Repeat the process until the number equals 1 (where it stays), or it loops endlessly in a cycle which does not include 1. Those numbers for which this process ends in 1 are happy numbers. Write a function `is_happy` that checks if a given positive integer is a happy number.\\n\\n#### Function Signature\\n```python\\ndef is_happy(n: int) -> bool:\\n```\\n\\n#### Input\\n- `n` (int): A positive integer.\\n\\n#### Output\\n- Returns `True` if the input number is happy, `False` otherwise.\\n\", \"code\": \"def is_happy(n: int) -> bool:\\n    seen = set()\\n    while n != 1 and n not in seen:\\n        seen.add(n)\\n        n = sum(int(i) ** 2 for i in str(n))\\n    return n == 1\", \"tests\": [\"assert is_happy(19) == True\", \"assert is_happy(2) == False\", \"assert is_happy(13) == True\", \"assert is_happy(11) == True\"] }"
